6C6776765C384F15B30650CDCB25EFE8.description: LACL.E.41: acquire and use accurately general academic and domain-specific words and phrases, sufficient for reading, writing, speaking, and listening at the college and career readiness level; demonstrate independence in gathering vocabulary knowledge when considering a word or phrase important to comprehension or expression

0FF599CD6EA9414BA98B3C13616BB0AE.description: LACL.E.40.b: analyze nuances in the meaning of words with similar denotations

B04421700E71441EBCF01AEA47597325.description: LACL.E.40.a: interpret figures of speech (e.g., hyperbole, paradox) in context and analyze their role in the text

C3D9D1BCB53E4DAD989D26E7A5A32860.description: LACL.E.40: demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word meanings

00350F1BE0AF41F487D0B8697AD47ECA.description: LACL.E.39.e: verify the preliminary determination of the meaning of a word or phrase (e.g., by checking the inferred meaning in context or in a dictionary)

A05F70915E5946B8AEE51C40DB94B1C0.description: LACL.E.39.d: consult general and specialized reference materials, both print and digital, to find the pronunciation of a word or determine or clarify its precise meaning, its part of speech, its etymology, or its standard usage

13ABDD69477942F58D08B9D169DB6E53.description: LACL.E.39.c: identify and correctly use patterns of word changes that indicate different meanings or parts of speech (e.g., conceive, conception, conceivable)

10644C1DEDF64D5FB137DB665E35E50F.description: LACL.E.39.b: use common, grade-appropriate Greek and Latin roots as clues to the meanings of words or phrases (e.g., colloquial, elocution, eloquent)

34463609C87D4947B3B5351C270BA61F.description: LACL.E.39.a: use context (e.g., the overall meaning of a sentence, paragraph, or text; a word's position or function in a sentence) as a clue to the meaning of a word or phrase

B7D78D3A3F964C9894B9EB807E0AD404.description: LACL.E.39: determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grades 11-12 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies

F4E54BFFC617461FA8970D98CEF9F942.description: LACL.E.38.a: vary syntax for effect, consulting references (e.g., Tufte's Artful Sentences) for guidance as needed; apply an understanding of syntax to the study of complex texts when reading

AB90442F931542BC852219F6ACB1C195.description: LACL.E.38: apply knowledge of language to understand how language functions in different contexts, to make effective choices for meaning or style, and to comprehend more fully when reading or listening

96E68DC5034744A8AC4E30F7955DF90F.description: LACL.E.37: demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing

3ED7B4DFE02A45CC86D70BB0CE0C889E.description: LACL.E.36.b: resolve issues of complex or contested usage, consulting references (e.g., Merriam-Webster's Dictionary of English Usage, Garner's Modern American Usage) as needed

C688FF550B7C4836AE60551CEA5D14F9.description: LACL.E.36.a: apply the understanding that usage is a matter of convention, can change over time, and is sometimes contested

E3CC545EB77643CA90E4FE9BCA5D4CF8.description: LACL.E.36: demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking

1E119D7389A44C689025CCB6EF45BB4F.description: LACL.D.35: adapt speech to a variety of contexts and tasks, demonstrating a command of formal English when indicated or appropriate

297C5C29313B4712A940AC30508D9A54.description: LACL.D.34.c: articulate ideas of bias, prejudice, and the like, in explaining the various viewpoints, theories, ideas of an author

42592AB1A86443AB96ED68AF12D19D58.description: LACL.D.34.b: evaluate the validity of sources, using primary and secondary sources, about the subject matter

C7DBA4D5DB85477FBFB8CBEA2E751213.description: LACL.D.34.a: analyze various sources, and articulate the central idea, and any supporting ideas, objectively

25B6E39744584AC49701722C0B909D62.description: LACL.D.34: make strategic use of digital media (e.g., textual, graphical, audio, visual, and interactive elements) in presentations to enhance understanding of findings, reasoning, and evidence and to add interest

68C22D7DB1974A04B41160E11031B14A.description: LACL.D.33: present information, findings, and supporting evidence, conveying a clear and distinct perspective, such that listeners can follow the line of reasoning, alternative or opposing perspectives are addressed, and the organization, development, substance, and style are appropriate to purpose, audience, and a range of formal and informal tasks

21C9FCD1CF2242EF84B250E026E87EF4.description: LACL.D.32.d: establish an unbiased and appropriate tone when creating arguments to avoid showing favoritism to the tone of the original source and voice

B9716D7288FC4D57881A9CD907DFCE77.description: LACL.D.32.c: use socially and culturally appropriate language to critique arguments

8D8F530769E14ABCBA5360E8F5934CEF.description: LACL.D.32.b: evaluate the author's argument considering bias, political climate, and voice and identify strengths and weaknesses of effectiveness

300B76D5D90745B29268F89D7C3BAF27.description: LACL.D.32.a: analyze an argument considering the speaker's background, voice, bias, and perspective and effectively identify the strengths and weaknesses in order to challenge the known points of view and incorporate the unheard points of view

4DC3428D98174D968E1BBF0E0B6FF72E.description: LACL.D.32: evaluate a speaker's point of view, reasoning, and use of evidence and rhetoric, assessing the stance, premises, links among ideas, word choice, points of emphasis, and tone used

27BAE4DB72164B8193000A82F8F85ABB.description: LACL.D.31: integrate multiple sources of information presented in diverse formats and media (e.g., visually, quantitatively, orally) in order to make informed decisions and solve problems, evaluating the credibility and accuracy of each source and noting any discrepancies among the data

FE6AE5DB58FC477BA9588B4CDA0D5601.description: LACL.D.30.f: compose arguments implementing multiple points of view without utilizing bias or so incorporating social commentary

D9F88DDF9F6E40CD9F785EFEB6FE9D93.description: LACL.D.30.e: improve conversations by incorporating diverse and inclusive questions that probe reasoning and evidence

DFCD3E201D834C6FAB7AFA86235CA5C7.description: LACL.D.30.d: work with peers to promote civil and inclusive discussions and decision-making, set clear goals and deadlines, and establish individual roles as needed

1F772E8108DB4F30BDAE5F2B76C62116.description: LACL.D.30.c: challenge ideas of bias to identify unheard perspectives and articulate obvious and neglected points of view/perspectives

31EC9B3A83FF458FBB406940E7742AD6.description: LACL.D.30.b: come to discussions having researched various unbiased sources, being prepared to speak with vast knowledge of multiple perspectives

BAF4F16DF0E44ADBA836694E5F539789.description: LACL.D.30.a: initiate civil discussion with partners who agree and disagree with a stated claim, idea, or topic

FA40DC7879404F3F8EE8DCF78EB00FC8.description: LACL.D.30: initiate and participate effectively in a range of collaborative discussions (e.g., one-on-one, in groups, and teacher-led) with diverse partners on grades 11-12 topics, texts, and issues, building on others' ideas and expressing their own clearly and persuasively

A364A79734DB4B318EAB6FA125266A8E.description: LACL.C.29: write routinely over extended time frames (time for research, reflection, and revision) and shorter time frames (a single sitting or a day or two) for a range of tasks, purposes, and audiences

47EF94F4E6B64707B49A3EFB79E6F2C9.description: LACL.C.28.g: establish connection among observations made in the text in order to support critical analysis and reflection

055BEBE735234E6388C0E9567B45BC58.description: LACL.C.28.f: produce a written reflection on an informational text that reflects on the meaning and value of a piece of writing

C73F7954341B40F197E81D87D52E737C.description: LACL.C.28.e: produce a written reflection to literature that reflects on the meaning and value of a piece of writing

D01132B6A69E4BF395BEBA46890D9C45.description: LACL.C.28.d: produce a written critical analysis of an informational text that draws evidence from the text

FC729F227D114F928C9C3601767211EE.description: LACL.C.28.c: produce a written critical analysis to literature that draws evidence from the text

FDC485411D184C5FA64DDBAD2751EB28.description: LACL.C.28.b: apply grades 11-12 reading standards to informational texts (e.g., delineate and evaluate the reasoning in seminal U.S. texts, including the application of constitutional principles and use of legal reasoning and the premises, purposes, and arguments in works of public advocacy)

07B4312810754838ADC662ACFB0F046D.description: LACL.C.28.a: apply grades 11-12 reading standards to literature (e.g., demonstrate knowledge of 18th, 19th, and early 20th-century works of multicultural literature, including how two or more texts from the same period treat similar themes or topics)

C0E0ED67BE82430C91F1B69369816242.description: LACL.C.28: draw evidence from literary or informational texts to support analysis, reflection, and research

7DD94339A02D4465A18BE5AB5DF68267.description: LACL.C.27: gather relevant information from multiple authoritative print and digital sources, using advanced searches effectively; assess the strengths and limitations of each source in terms of the task, purpose, and audience; integrate information into the text selectively to maintain the flow of ideas, avoiding plagiarism and overreliance on any one source and following a standard format for citation

8A6C9C26EDCD4F96975729C146850198.description: LACL.C.26: conduct short, as well as more sustained, research projects to answer questions (including self-generated questions) or solve problems; narrow or broaden the inquiries when appropriate; synthesize multiple sources on the subjects, demonstrating understanding of the subjects under investigation

65570C5BC5D144C681543F48C7058F56.description: LACL.C.25: use technology, including the Internet, to produce, publish, and update individual or shared writing products in response to ongoing feedback, including new arguments or information

DF120FE4DE5F4CC38249010CA9142829.description: LACL.C.24: develop and strengthen writing as needed by planning, revising, editing, rewriting, or trying a new approach, focusing on addressing what is most significant for a specific purpose and audience

AE0832B0FD874973A8B0583DB1AFFAEA.description: LACL.C.23.b: produce writing that engages the reader, sets a context for their topic/issue, and establishes an organizational structure

D208B52354D44D3AB3A892034AEFC867.description: LACL.C.23.a: use writing techniques in a clear and organized way that demonstrates stylistic liberties that target a specific audience

930235169D1D4F2A90232BF572C431E8.description: LACL.C.23: produce clear and coherent writing in which the development, organization, and style are appropriate to task, purpose, and audience

1B3743062B9046B693D5695154A8A106.description: LACL.C.22.e: provide a conclusion that follows from and reflects on what is experienced, observed, or resolved over the course of the narrative

A6543EDDDD7B45CFA9C6345266C81BAF.description: LACL.C.22.d: use precise words and phrases, telling details, and sensory language to convey a vivid picture of the experiences, events, setting, and/or characters

5638087022264E76BA33327933191CF0.description: LACL.C.22.c: use a variety of techniques to sequence events so that they build on one another to create a coherent whole and build toward a particular tone and outcome (e.g., a sense of mystery, suspense, growth, or resolution)

C25EAA9246B64B408005A3EF3C6682CA.description: LACL.C.22.b: use narrative techniques, such as dialogue, pacing, description, reflection, and multiple plot lines, to develop experiences, events, and/or characters

CE975B8C863B45E2BDA0C75761350055.description: LACL.C.22.a: engage and orient the reader by setting out a problem, situation, or observation and its significance, establishing one or multiple point(s) of view, and introducing a narrator and/or characters; create a smooth progression of experiences or events

C71B4FC126654C80AD11123AB565ED99.description: LACL.C.22: write narratives to develop real or imagined experiences or events, using effective technique, well-chosen details, and well-structured event sequences

E060115D3C46476AB611F621978F962B.description: LACL.C.21.i: use culturally and socially-relevant language to articulate ideas of the designated topic

7F9328D8DF8D46BE884733F6754ECB54.description: LACL.C.21.h: compose informative texts without incorporating bias, prejudice, or other subjective language

3459CA95C2274BA5ABC5A5A57CD21FFE.description: LACL.C.21.g: provide a concluding statement or section that follows from and supports the information or explanation presented (e.g., articulating implications or the significance of the topic)

6574CABE485249D8AB017BBE78033610.description: LACL.C.21.f: use documents to clarify details or support claims

088AB35CDACD4036B7273C7A60BBB1B9.description: LACL.C.21.e: establish and maintain a formal style and objective tone while attending to the norms and conventions of the discipline in which they are writing

E048F63074F144C38C1BFDDCC8F3973F.description: LACL.C.21.d: use precise language, domain-specific vocabulary, and techniques such as metaphor, simile, and analogy to manage the complexity of the topic

48437605F5FD48CC866BC790F575B36A.description: LACL.C.21.c: use appropriate and varied transitions and syntax to link the major sections of the text, create cohesion, and clarify the relationships among complex ideas and concepts

10A9322F290E4896A17161FA198AC7C7.description: LACL.C.21.b: develop the topic thoroughly by selecting the most significant and relevant facts, extended definitions, concrete details, quotations, or other information and examples appropriate to the audience's knowledge of the topic

7124784127C14E7891C86AC90148E164.description: LACL.C.21.a: introduce a topic; organize complex ideas, concepts, and information so that each new element builds on that which precedes it to create a unified whole; include formatting (e.g., headings), graphics (e.g., figures, tables), and multimedia when useful to aiding comprehension

F63D9A5951DD423891D610C36CB7F605.description: LACL.C.21: write informative/explanatory texts to examine and convey complex ideas, concepts, and information clearly and accurately through the effective selection, organization, and analysis of content

70D03517039C4AD2A9B88061D2AA7CBE.description: LACL.C.20.e: provide a concluding statement or section that follows from and supports the argument presented

4ADBCE3952E04AC7A991DC65F9EFA934.description: LACL.C.20.d: establish and maintain a formal style and objective tone while attending to the norms and conventions of the discipline in which they are writing

9460CEACED0145ABB3C0CFF7E696A85C.description: LACL.C.20.c: use words, phrases, and clauses as well as varied syntax to link the major sections of the text, create cohesion, and clarify the relationships between claim(s) and reasons, between reasons and evidence, and between claim(s) and counterclaims

81FE456E8D9C4C5CAD1E39F1383D8C7B.description: LACL.C.20.b: develop claim(s) and counterclaims fairly and thoroughly, supplying the most relevant evidence for each while pointing out the strengths and limitations of both in a manner that anticipates the audience's knowledge level, concerns, values, and possible biases

273806FFF99542FB82B35E9076AD6B0B.description: LACL.C.20.a: introduce precise, knowledgeable claim(s), establish the significance of the claim(s), distinguish the claim(s) from alternate or opposing claims, and create an organization that logically sequences claim(s), counterclaims, reasons, and evidence

9169C9819512455BB64DB3F2558175B7.description: LACL.C.20: write arguments to support claims in an analysis of substantive topics or texts, using valid reasoning and relevant and sufficient evidence

1729B03DE2BE4ED2843783A6DB67FD0C.description: LACL.B.19.c: read, comprehend, and analyze informational texts written by authors of different races, ethnicities, religions, genders, sexual orientations, disabilities, and languages

DA3AF3FA12C94111A3EBEB1EE25437D6.description: LACL.B.19.b: read, comprehend, and analyze informational texts that are inclusive of different races, ethnicities, religions, genders, sexual orientations, disabilities, and languages

8258AE7C213C4797944353277337D6C2.description: LACL.B.19.a: read, comprehend, and analyze informational texts about the sociocultural experiences of underrepresented groups

C2C1F03DA3F2427E960F0D0D9ED2E9E6.description: LACL.B.19: read and comprehend informational texts at the high end of the grades 11-CCR text complexity band independently and proficiently, by the end of grade 12

7C1897D61F0F4B84922EFB152C2C0BBD.description: LACL.B.18.a: relate a literary work to primary source documents of its literary period or historical setting

80C085CFAE0E4ADA844DB20F8FAA7506.description: LACL.B.18: analyze foundational documents of historical and literary significance for their themes, purposes, and rhetorical features

64667B818C814AC48B025C53D27BA480.description: LACL.B.17: delineate and evaluate the reasoning in seminal U.S. texts, including the application of constitutional principles and use of legal reasoning and the premises, purposes, and arguments in works of public advocacy

41F27C1A5B3D45CBB6199E12479C1E36.description: LACL.B.16: integrate and evaluate multiple sources of information presented in different media or formats (e.g., visually, quantitatively) as well as in words in order to address a question or solve a problem

48E69AD40A9D4238BE2974FDE65382A8.description: LACL.B.15.h: determine an author's or speaker's point of view even when it is not stated explicitly

A3829FB067CA40459E1915F8C21BBA95.description: LACL.B.15.g: distinguish between a powerful and a valid argument

0A8B142D60284C858D56F81C88ACDD7F.description: LACL.B.15.f: identify author biases, both subtle and overt, and make considered decisions regarding the validity of a claim or appeal

75C71C06DB2F4DAC941C510B64759CFD.description: LACL.B.15.e: analyze and evaluate the logic and use of evidence in an author's argument

64ACBBF91EAC40C9A95B8B64F2C5A733.description: LACL.B.15.d: identify author biases, both subtle and overt, including implicit and explicit assumptions

01C53E44BCD64BB68C6DE4CEA3894F29.description: LACL.B.15.c: understand and apply knowledge of diction, syntax, tone, imagery, figurative language, and other elements in determining the effectiveness of an argument or exposition

8909C3EADC944EF7A473D451D8474416.description: LACL.B.15.b: understand and identify rhetorical strategies such as appeals to emotion or authority and logical fallacies

68F321CC5F224BAB97519AF696F58EC6.description: LACL.B.15.a: analyze and compare topics and themes characteristic of particular cultures or of multicultural literature across culture and genres as connected to cultural values and traditions

F85EB8E9430947C9B8D1139EE2D7C94A.description: LACL.B.15: determine an author's point of view or purpose in a text in which the rhetoric is particularly effective, analyzing how style and content contribute to the power, persuasiveness, or beauty of the text

2599D06673DE44BDA1C7477EC409A0FA.description: LACL.B.14.c: analyze the uniqueness or differences in structural decisions across multicultural writing; evaluate the effectiveness in conveying arguments to broader audiences

5AA4775E390C4C26AA296C56B02A287D.description: LACL.B.14.b: evaluate the different structures a single author uses over the course of his/her writing life and compare with that of another author

BF059C1C6A4441379C3B24E8EF89B4D4.description: LACL.B.14.a: determine the personal, political, societal, and philosophical influences on authors that impacted how they structured their arguments

25191110D8AF400492E66C0F92B89C43.description: LACL.B.14: analyze and evaluate the effectiveness of the structure an author uses in his or her exposition or argument, including whether the structure makes points clear, convincing, and engaging

0E3097CB7B2B425787C87B6671ACEA3F.description: LACL.B.13.e: analyze the effect of certain words/phrases in contemporary conversations on race, ethnicity, sexual identity, and pop culture

ADAB878CE1C04C9CBF06222CA8704A99.description: LACL.B.13.d: delineate the differences between the effect of a particular term towards a particular group of people and the way the same term is used within that particular group of people

D9D3334D5D354631B8DAFFC2280753EF.description: LACL.B.13.c: determine the effects of words and phrases on individuals and groups

A21C53C9F00E42C49FF78749150071D0.description: LACL.B.13.b: determine the effects of the cultural environment on/in the text and analyze how an author uses specific language for specific audiences

21C4C40654564D5082795EF9A9B0CEE3.description: LACL.B.13.a: analyze how authors strategically use and refine the meaning of key terms over the course of a text and how this refinement contributes to the understanding of both the terms and perspective shown

564A90610BAE44B2879D620F6FD8FF6C.description: LACL.B.13: determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings; analyze how an author uses and refines the meaning of a key term or terms over the course of a text

D9CE4C518A0A4E6CBCBB13669FE3EFE2.description: LACL.B.12: analyze a complex set of ideas or sequence of events and explain how specific individuals, ideas, or events interact and develop over the course of the text to create a distinct perspective

5AA485DEE35A47EABB39A8EE619678A0.description: LACL.B.11.d: compare the development of the ideas in the text with the development of similar ideas in a modern or contemporary text

E4D4A0269FD14B95AE14B7BC569D966A.description: LACL.B.11.c: determine the core ideas that initiated a particular action or event in a text

C6DC8688BE1647E6935C1492A2670C5A.description: LACL.B.11.b: analyze how sociocultural issues impact the subjects of the text

43D82F16405A467993C433A6F1042EED.description: LACL.B.11.a: track complex ideas within an informational text, particularly as they relate to ideas that emerge in multicultural texts

79EB8E0B3D674D188C049F799C42B0AC.description: LACL.B.11: determine two or more central ideas of a text and analyze their development over the course of the text, including how they interact and build on one another to provide a complex analysis; provide an objective summary of the text

9D6F43FDF5BC4F0B866D82DB14CDFCFC.description: LACL.B.10.c: analyze issues/subjects that are left uncertain in texts

BE7AE62D8CDB4272A230F1FD0550BEC9.description: LACL.B.10.b: construct an argument using textual evidence that addresses common ideas in multicultural texts

DBAC1EEC9B4443CE94C251310AD55987.description: LACL.B.10.a: draw inferences and conclusions about a range of texts representing diverse topics and authors

7AB4E007C7654C3E9E68BD00F0F4CF29.description: LACL.B.10: cite strong and thorough textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text, including determining where the text leaves matters uncertain

DECB0DD72CA240D2A1537C73DB50F8D7.description: LACL.A.9.c: read, comprehend, and analyze literature written by authors of different races, ethnicities, religions, genders, sexual orientations, disabilities, and languages

E42ADD119C8C4FC883452420295A9AD1.description: LACL.A.9.b: read, comprehend, and analyze literature that is inclusive of characters of different races, ethnicities, religions, genders, sexual orientations, disabilities, and languages

6F89B1912FE346D4BA286E69C7F56B0E.description: LACL.A.9.a: read, comprehend, and analyze literature about the sociocultural experiences of underrepresented groups

7681F16D45A7410FA7DD7CB8EEBAB681.description: LACL.A.9: read and comprehend literature, including stories, dramas, and poems, at the high end of the grades 11-CCR text complexity band independently and proficiently, by the end of grade 12

831DAC7736CD48F090A043DF4312B199.description: LACL.A.8: demonstrate knowledge of 18th, 19th, and early 20th-century works of multicultural literature, including how two or more texts from the same period treat similar themes or topics

FB111AD82F50410CBF3AEEC041677422.description: LACL.A.7: analyze multiple interpretations of a story, drama, or poem (e.g., recorded or live production of a play or recorded novel or poetry), evaluating how each version interprets the source text

9AC63BC77FDD45A08C5739A06497A8DC.description: LACL.A.6.g: analyze how the author reveals that characters make assumptions about others

C5A1E13DFBBA46758D0360689C0F11DE.description: LACL.A.6.f: analyze the way the author gets the reader to doubt, trust, or sympathize with a character's perspective across pages

D89B1014A7A742A9B7810C42484FCBF9.description: LACL.A.6.e: analyze how the beliefs and values of the community, as well as the characters' histories and cultures shape characters' perspectives

EE01716FC6134259926117D4ED259D38.description: LACL.A.6.d: analyze how characters' perspectives are shaped by their histories and cultures as well as their current environments

37863B1B526A40DF836071A9C077036D.description: LACL.A.6.c: analyze how the text reveals more hidden perspectives or raises questions about perspectives that are presented

578EBDC80D0E488C8C8053A5CA13B78A.description: LACL.A.6.b: analyze which perspectives are more visible in the story, and which may be hidden, marginalized, or missing

6C804D32A96342B6833C27331D310C1B.description: LACL.A.6.a: examine connections between an author's choices about point of view and cultural conventions and traditions in oral and/or written language

1A1D2BD9BF0F419FBC5A84927C4EACAC.description: LACL.A.6: analyze a case in which grasping point of view requires distinguishing what is directly stated in a text from what is really meant (e.g., satire, sarcasm, irony, or understatement)

83D4268BC8434986A887F71134263023.description: LACL.A.5: analyze how an author's choices concerning how to structure specific parts of a text (e.g., the choice of where to begin or end a story, the choice to provide a comedic or tragic resolution) contribute to its overall structure and meaning as well as its aesthetic impact

946891816B5A44DDADFD32D22C2B9D60.description: LACL.A.4.e: examine the impact of colloquialisms and not-standard language that is important to the text and to the presentation of the characters

1F566BDF70B34E6980D523763F2BFDEB.description: LACL.A.4.d: analyze the effect of certain words/phrases in contemporary conversations on race, ethnicity, sexual identity and pop culture

50CB1C8137A14B0AB94B37A94D9340F4.description: LACL.A.4.c: delineate the differences between the effect of particular terms towards a group of people and the way the same term is used within that group of people

99EFF8A36AA743008741932BDB886742.description: LACL.A.4.b: determine the effects of certain words and phrases on individuals or groups

3DADC2AB18BB40718764D87ACB6982CB.description: LACL.A.4.a: determine the effects of the cultural environment on/in the text, and analyze how an author uses specific language for specific audiences

45CAB32839B3492FB566370FE0198478.description: LACL.A.4: determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in the text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone, including words with multiple meanings or language that is particularly fresh, engaging, or beautiful

E350A5A0073A402CA61BEF4F01CF245E.description: LACL.A.3.f: analyze how the dynamics between characters shift across a story, as well as how the characters affect the plot

FBA3AF5E86054F42B1E15F389A1556BC.description: LACL.A.3.e: analyze the role that minor characters play in the story

CCE38A507FA948E79D35EF4BF20AAFE5.description: LACL.A.3.d: analyze how character motivations are shaped by multiple pressures, and/or by systems and dynamics that are outside their control

7E86EE3C1CD24C29BACFF1D764BAB816.description: LACL.A.3.c: analyze how characters' decisions and motivations may be influenced by moments that occurred much earlier in the story, as well as how characters may be shaped by social pressures

772E6FA606094FF981E9C55316D38460.description: LACL.A.3.b: analyze how characters may be normative or transgressive (they fit with or break stereotypes), as well as how they fit with or transcend archetypes

95FCBAB1E32B4ADFA3E82843F37639F0.description: LACL.A.3.a: analyze hidden sides of characters, which take longer to reveal themselves, as well as parts of characters that may be contradictory

A3CD88FA3D0C496C8FC43D530F40B842.description: LACL.A.3: analyze the impact of the author's choices regarding how to develop and relate elements of a story or drama (e.g., where a story is set, how the action is ordered, how the characters are introduced and developed)

1C82F747027C4A25929B447D2EA8C3CD.description: LACL.A.2.d: determine how themes and issues develop across a story, including explaining how different story elements and narrative techniques contribute to these themes

269B83B82C314E3F9D6AEDBF27E5ECE0.description: LACL.A.2.c: determine how subtle details, that may seem less significant, matter in developing themes and issues

191EB50E3EA74AD6915D5069F63C3BD4.description: LACL.A.2.b: examine how some themes and issues in the story also exist in the outside world and are significant as social commentary

09FC86B2F23545B691FD097DA338B897.description: LACL.A.2.a: trace complex and nuanced themes and issues that emerge in different parts of the text, including social issues that are hinted at in the text

74FD542C401640FAB4B128A2C17811E9.description: LACL.A.2: determine two or more themes or central ideas of a text and analyze their development over the course of the text, including how they interact and build on one another to produce a complex account; provide an objective summary of the text

A66F4DBEF5724BA7B57E8F905E0B50E5.description: LACL.A.1.b: analyze issues/subjects that are left uncertain in multicultural literature

B888902A918D446C8F0559708DD0D923.description: LACL.A.1.a: draw inferences and conclusions from a wide range of multicultural literature

5C79B7A107C3461B97D82501FB01C8A2.description: LACL.A.1: cite strong and thorough textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text, including determining where the text leaves matters uncertain
